text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Editorial changes have been made throughout.
IRM 25.15.5, Relief from Community Property Laws , dated July 24, 2017 is

Employees who are working cases involving married taxpayers domiciled in community property states, or otherwise raising community property issues, including receiving requests for relief under IRC 66(c).
Table of Contents
Property Laws
) Purpose: This IRM section provides technical guidance on various relief sions of IRC
, Treatment of Community Income, and how to determine under this code section. (

) Audience: This IRM section is intended to address the needs of all Service employees working cases involving married taxpayers domiciled in property states that ﬁled separate returns or are non-ﬁlers. They include are not limited to: a. SB/SE Area Office examiners, such as Revenue Agents and Tax ance Officers. b. SB/SE Technical Services Reviewers. c. Financial Technicians and Specialists at the Centralized Cincinnati Innocent Spouse Operations (CCISO). d. Managers of the above listed employees. (
) Policy Owner: The Director, Examination - Field and Campus Policy, who under the Director, Headquarters Examination. (
) Program Owner: Campus Exam and Field Support, which is under the Director, Examination - Field and Campus Policy. (
) Program Goals: Determine how provisions of IRC

are applicable to taxpayers domiciled in a community property state who ﬁle separate are non-ﬁlers. Determine which taxpayers may be eligible for one of the community property income allocation exceptions of IRC
(a) or (b), or for innocent spouse relief under IRC
(c). See IRM
, Introduction, for more information. (

) Each spouse domiciled in a community property state is generally liable for income tax on one-half of the community income when the spouses do not a joint return. This section will discuss community property laws and outline provisions of IRC
, Treatment of Community Income. IRC
grants relief from the community property income splitting requirements in certain cumstances. Note: The existence of community property does not impact IRC
tions when a joint return is ﬁled. Under IRC
a spouse may be for relief from joint and several liabilities attributable to a joint return. minations under IRC
are made without regard to community (
) A spouse may be exempted from community property items attributable to other spouse under certain provisions of IRC
, and also by ﬁling a Form
, Request for Innocent Spouse Relief. (
) IRC

(c) relief is not available if the spouse: • Filed a joint return, • Transferred assets to the other spouse as part of a fraudulent • Entered into a closing agreement that disposes of the same liability, • Entered into an offer in compromise for the liability. (
) For further information on community property law not listed in this IRM, IRM
, Basic Principles of Community Property Law.
from Community Property Laws 25.15.5

SB/SE Area Office examiners, such as Revenue Agents and Tax ance Officers. SB/SE Technical Services Reviewers. Financial Technicians and Specialists at the Centralized Cincinnati Innocent Spouse Operations (CCISO). Managers of the above listed employees.
For further information on community property law not listed in this IRM, see IRM 25.18.1, Basic Principles of Community Property Law.
25.15 Relief from Joint and Several Liability
The information in this section is based upon the following authorities:

Area Office examiners, such as Revenue Agents and Tax Compliance Officers, are responsible for applying the provisions of IRC 66 fairly and consistently in determining whether relief provisions apply, as part of their examinations.
following table contains a list of terms used throughout this IRM:

Terms Deﬁnition Common Law A property system in which each spouse is treated as an indi- vidual, and each spouse owns and is taxed upon income that he or she earns. See IRM 25.18.1.2.1, Common Law, for more information. Community Property Generally all property acquired during a marriage while spouses are domiciled in a community property state. See IRM 25.15.5.5, Community and Separate Property, and IRM 25.18.1.3.10, Deﬁnition of Community Property, for more information.

Property Laws 25.15.5 page 3 Terms Deﬁnition Community Property Income Income earned by either or both spouses in a community property state that is not deemed separate property by other rules, or agree- ments between the spouses to maintain a separate property ownership regime. Community property income is typically taxed 50% to each spouse. See IRM 25.15.5.3, Treatment of Community Property Income in General, and IRM 25.18.2, Income Reporting Considerations of Community Property, for more information. Community Property Law A property system where the pre- sumption is that each spouse contributes income and assets to the “community” of the spouses, and share equally in any earnings, assets, and debts of the community. See IRM 25.18.1.2.2, Community Property Law, for more information. Community Property state States that use community property law as their property system. Each state’s law can vary based on the individual state statutes. See IRM 25.15.5.2, Community Property States, for more information. Innocent Spouse relief The relief from liabilities on joint or separately ﬁled returns requested by ﬁling a Form 8857, Request for Innocent Spouse Relief, or similar statement signed under penalties of perjury. See IRM 25.15.1, Introduction, for more information. Separate property Property and related income that is deemed separate property of one spouse. See IRM 25.15.5.5, Community and Separate Property, and IRM 25.18.1.3.11, Deﬁnition of Separate Property, for more information.

Income Reporting Considerations of Community Property, for more information. A property system where the pre- sumption is that each spouse contributes income and assets to the “community” of the spouses, and share equally in any earnings, assets, and debts of the community. See IRM
, Community Property Law, for more information. States that use community property law as their property system. Each state’s law can vary based on the individual state statutes. See IRM
, Community Property States, for more information. The relief from liabilities on joint or separately ﬁled returns requested by ﬁling a Form
, Request for Innocent Spouse Relief, or similar statement signed under penalties of perjury. See IRM
, Introduction, for more information. Property and related income that is deemed separate property of one spouse. See IRM
, Community and Separate Property, and IRM
, Deﬁnition of Separate Property, for more information.

Acronym Deﬁnition CCISO Cincinnati Centralized Innocent Spouse Operation - the campus location that works innocent spouse relief requests that are not worked in Area Office exami- nations. NRS Non-Requesting Spouse - the spouse not requesting innocent spouse relief. RS Requesting Spouse - the spouse requesting innocent spouse relief.

(07-24-2017) Community Property States
• Wisconsin Note: While not community property states, Alaska and Oklahoma do allow to elect a community property system. See Alaska Statutes §§
The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the Oklahoma statute would not be recognized for federal income tax reporting purposes. Commissioner v. Harmon,
U.S.
). The Harmon decision should also apply to the Alaska system for income reporting purposes. (
) Same-sex marriage: On June
in Oberfell v. Hodges,
S.Ct.

), the Supreme Court held that: a. State laws are invalid to the extent they exclude same-sex couples from civil marriage on the same terms and conditions as opposite-sex and b. All states must recognize same-sex marriages performed in other As a result, same-sex married couples receive the same state and federal beneﬁts and burdens as opposite-sex married couples. Therefore, same-sex couples who domicile in a community property state are subject to property rules in the same manner as opposite-sex married couples. (

) Registered domestic partners in Nevada, Washington, or California generally must follow state community property laws and report half the combined community income of the individual and his or her registered domestic See Cal. Fam. Code §
(a); Nev. Rev. Stat. §
A
; Wash. Rev. §
These laws are summarized in Exhibit
, Comparison of Internal Revenue Manual

Registered domestic partners are not married for federal tax purposes. They may not ﬁle married ﬁling jointly or married ﬁling separately federal income tax returns. See
, Registered Domestic Partners, for more information. (
) Some countries are community property, and the law of each country should be checked as necessary. (
) The community property territories of the United States are: • Guam • Puerto Rico (

) Community property laws vary greatly from state to state based upon each dividual state’s statutes. The community property laws of the state where Community spouses are domiciled controls and must be reviewed when any tax issue involves the application of community property laws. See Exhibit
, Comparison of State Law Differences in Community Property States, at
for more information. (

) Spouses domiciled in community property states may ﬁle tax returns either jointly or separately. The spouses generally have an undivided one-half in the community income; so any separate return should reﬂect one-half of community income plus

% of their separate income. Note: Taxpayers with a prenuptial agreement can opt out of state community property laws and elect to have income treated as if they were domiciled non-community property state, in which case IRC
would not apply. See IRM
, Premarital and Post-Marital Contracts Between for more information. (

) For federal tax purposes, a taxpayer’s rights and interest in property are mined under the laws of the taxpayer’s state of domicile. The words “residence” and “domicile” are not synonymous and are often confused. A residence is where a taxpayer lives. A domicile is a permanent home the taxpayer intends to use for an indeﬁnite or unlimited period, and when intends to return. A taxpayer may have several places of residence, but only one domicile. See IRM
, Domicile, for more information. (

) Objective factors are a good indication of the taxpayer’s intent. Such factors include: a. Where the taxpayer is employed. b. Whether the taxpayer is on temporary work detail, attending school or stationed in the military. c. Where the taxpayer’s vehicles are registered. d. Where the taxpayer ﬁles state tax returns. e. Where the taxpayer is registered to vote. f. Where the taxpayer’s personal residence is located. g. Where the taxpayer’s family is located. h. Where the taxpayer is involved with the community.

For federal tax purposes, a taxpayer’s rights and interest in property are mined under the laws of the taxpayer’s state of domicile. The words “residence” and “domicile” are not synonymous and are often confused. A residence is where a taxpayer lives. A domicile is a permanent home the taxpayer intends to use for an indeﬁnite or unlimited period, and when absent, intends to return. A taxpayer may have several places of residence, but only one domicile. See IRM
, Domicile, for more information.

Community Property Laws
) If both spouses have different domiciles, you should check the community property laws of each state to determine if they have community property or community income. (
) Community Property - Generally, community property is all property during a marriage while the spouses are domiciled in a community property state. See IRM

, Deﬁnition of Community Property, for more mation. Additional guidelines listed below are the general rules regarding constitutes community property: • Property both spouses agree to convert from separate to community property • Property which cannot be identiﬁed as separate property (

) Separate Property - Generally, for property to be considered separate after marriage, it must be acquired by separate funds. For property acquired marriage to remain separate, the upkeep must be done by separate funds the property must not be commingled with community property. See IRM
, Deﬁnition of Separate Property, for more information. (
) Generally, community income is income generated from community For additional information, see IRM

, Income Reporting of Community Property, for additional information. Listed below are the rules regarding what constitutes community income: • Income, rents, dividends, and/or interest derived from community property • Salaries, wages, or pay for the services of either spouse during the marriage • Economic beneﬁts attributable to the efforts of the spouse (for income reported on Schedules C, E, or F) (

) State law must be reviewed to determine the proper treatment for income. Also, state law will determine how to treat community income if the spouses have separated during the year. Each state’s laws regarding community income and community property are different. Do not assume general rules apply in every state. See IRM Exhibit
, Comparison State Law Differences in Community Property States, for more information. (

) The effect of innocent spouse relief is to make a spouse no longer liable for particular tax. It removes or prevents the assessment of tax against a It does not affect the ability of the Service to pursue collection remedies against the nonliable spouse’s interest in community property. See United States v. Stolle,

(g) does not override the Service’s ability to offset payments made from community property under state law. Subject to other limitations in the

to receive refunds of certain payments they have made toward the liability. However, the Service may still be able to retain all or part of the payments that would otherwise be refundable under IRC 6015(g) if they were made from community property and the Service has a state law remedy against the community property. See Ordlock v. Commissioner, 126 T.C. 47(2006).

) IRC
has three subsections that could affect the reporting of community property income. a. IRC

(c) grants relief to spouses from reporting half of particular of community property income. See IRM

(c) Spouse Relief, for more information. (

applies only to community income, as deﬁned by state law. Some of the requirements of the section can be quite complex. (
) IRC

does not negate liability that arises against a spouse under the operation of other (non-community property) laws. For example: • It will not negate transferee liability if it applies. See Treas. Reg.

(c) for more information. • It does not negate any collection remedies based on state law community property in the hands of the other spouse. Example: Husband and wife live in Arizona. Both owe taxes. Wife relief under IRC

) Where IRC

(c) applies, the items of community property upon which the questing Spouse (RS) receives relief are included in the income of the Non- Requesting Spouse (NRS), but only as long as the statute of limitations is open. (
) Requests for relief under IRC
(c), except for equitable relief, usually are required to be ﬁled before the statute of limitations on assessment expires the NRS’s year subject to the request. (
) The time for ﬁling a claim for equitable relief under IRC
(c) is not tied into the statute of limitations for assessments against the NRS. See IRM
, Time Period for Filing a Request for Relief, for more information. (
) Consideration should be given to protecting the statute of limitations of the NRS if it is still open when the request is received. (
) If the shifting of the income creates a deﬁciency for the NRS, then procedures apply to assess the additional tax.

(h) for more information. (
) Under IRC

(a), if spouses meet certain requirements, they do not report most community property income under community property rules. IRC of provides an exception to the general rule that community income is taxed Income half to each spouse domiciled in a community property state. This is a Live rule that allocates earned income to the spouse who earned the income if certain statutory requirements are met. It applies where: a. The spouses are married to each other at any time during the year; b. The spouses live apart at all times during the calendar year. For purposes of this requirement, living apart requires that spouses separate residences; Note: Spouses who maintain separate residences due to temporary absences are not considered to be living apart. See Treas. Reg.

(b) for more information. c. The spouses do not ﬁle a joint return with each other for the taxable beginning or ending in the calendar year; d. One or both of the spouses have earned income for the calendar which is community income; and e. No portion of the earned income is transferred between the spouses, directly or indirectly, before the close of the calendar year. income does not include de minimis amounts of earned income trans- ferred between spouses. Amounts transferred for the beneﬁt of the spouses’ child are not treated as direct or indirect transfers of Income transferred between spouses is presumed to be a transfer of earned income, although the presumption is rebuttable. See Treas.
(c) for more information. (
) If all of these criteria are met, spouses in community property states must report their income according to rules of IRC
(a) which provides: a. Earned income (within the meaning of section

)), other than or business income and a partner’s distributive share of partnership income, shall be treated as the income of the spouse who rendered personal services. b. Trade or business income is taxed to the spouse who owns the unless the other spouse exercised substantially all of the and control of the business, in which case it is treated as the other spouse’s income. ) and IRC
). c. A distributive share from a partnership is taxed to the spouse who is partner. d. Income derived from the separate property of the one spouse is that spouse. See IRC

(c) as to partnership items) that disposes of the same liability that is the subject of the request for relief. The RS has entered into an offer in compromise with the Service for the liability. See Treas. Reg.
(h) for more information.

Under IRC 66(a), if spouses meet certain requirements, they do not report most community property income under community property rules. IRC 66(a) provides an exception to the general rule that community income is taxed one- half to each spouse domiciled in a community property state. This is a special rule that allocates earned income to the spouse who earned the income if
Under IRC
(a), if spouses meet certain requirements, they do not report most community property income under community property rules. IRC

(a) provides an exception to the general rule that community income is taxed one- half to each spouse domiciled in a community property state. This is a special rule that allocates earned income to the spouse who earned the income if certain statutory requirements are met. It applies where:

The spouses are married to each other at any time during the calendar year; The spouses live apart at all times during the calendar year. For purposes of this requirement, living apart requires that spouses maintain separate residences;

The spouses do not ﬁle a joint return with each other for the taxable beginning or ending in the calendar year; One or both of the spouses have earned income for the calendar year, which is community income; and No portion of the earned income is transferred between the spouses, directly or indirectly, before the close of the calendar year. Transferred income does not include de minimis amounts of earned income trans- ferred between spouses. Amounts transferred for the beneﬁt of the spouses’ child are not treated as direct or indirect transfers of income. Income transferred between spouses is presumed to be a transfer of earned income, although the presumption is rebuttable. See Treas.
(c) for more information.

d. One or both of the spouses have earned income for the calendar year, which is community income; and e. No portion of the earned income is transferred between the spouses, directly or indirectly, before the close of the calendar year. Transferred income does not include de minimis amounts of earned income trans- ferred between spouses. Amounts transferred for the beneﬁt of the spouses’ child are not treated as direct or indirect transfers of income. Income transferred between spouses is presumed to be a transfer of earned income, although the presumption is rebuttable. See Treas. Reg.
(c) for more information. If all of these criteria are met, spouses in community property states must report their income according to rules of IRC
(a) which provides: a. Earned income (within the meaning of section

)), other than trade or business income and a partner’s distributive share of partnership income, shall be treated as the income of the spouse who rendered the personal services. b. Trade or business income is taxed to the spouse who owns the business unless the other spouse exercised substantially all of the management and control of the business, in which case it is treated as the other spouse’s income. See IRC
) and IRC
). c. A distributive share from a partnership is taxed to the spouse who is the partner. d. Income derived from the separate property of the one spouse is taxed to that spouse. See IRC

All other forms of income are taxed in accordance with normal community property laws. See IRC 879(a)(4). This includes dividend, interest, rents, royalties, capital gains, and earnings of unemancipated minor children.
community property laws. See IRC
). This includes dividend, interest, rents, royalties, capital gains, and earnings unemancipated minor children. (
) IRC
(b) provides an exception to the general rule that community income taxed one-half to each spouse. IRC
(b) authorizes the Service to disregard community property laws by denying the beneﬁts of income splitting between the spouses. IRC

(b) may be applied under the following conditions: a. The spouse acted as if he/she was solely entitled to such community income, and b. The spouse failed to notify the other spouse of the nature and amount such income before the due date of the return (including extensions) the taxable year in which the income was derived. (
) IRC
(b) entitles the Service to shift the item of income and assess tax against the spouse earning the income in accordance with deﬁciency cedures. See IRC
(b) and Treas. Reg.
) Only the Service can invoke IRC
(b). It is not a relief provision that can be invoked by a taxpayer to escape liability. Hardy v. Commissioner,

(b) applies. If the notice to do this, the burden of proof may be shifted to the Service. Shea v. sioner,
T.C.

) Solely entitled to income: to determine whether a spouse has acted as if he she was solely entitled to the income, consider the facts and circumstances focusing on whether the spouse used, or made available, the item of income for the beneﬁt of the marital community. See Treas. Reg.

(a). For instance: • Where the community property at issue is deposited into a joint or an account over which both spouses have signature authority, this a strong indication that the spouse who deposited the funds did not as though he or she was solely entitled to the funds. Cox v. Commis- sioner, T.C. Memo.
; Drummer v. Commissioner, T.C. Memo.
, aff’d without published opinion,
F.
d
th Cir.
). • Similarly, where a spouse sends a portion of the funds to the other spouse, that spouse has not acted as though he or she was solely entitled to the funds. Mischel v. Commissioner, T.C. Memo
; Treas. Reg.
(c), Example
(ii). • If the community income is retained by one spouse and spent at his her discretion, that spouse has acted as though he or she was solely entitled to the income. See Treas. Reg.
(c), Example
(i) for information. (

or Form W-
to the other spouse satisﬁes the notiﬁcation of the nature and amount of income requirement. If notiﬁcation is done before the

Notiﬁcation of nature and amount of income: a spouse who provides a copy of a Form 1099 or Form W-2 to the other spouse satisﬁes the notiﬁcation of the nature and amount of income requirement. If notiﬁcation is done before the
Property Laws
page due date of the return (including extensions), IRC
(b) is inapplicable. See Treas. Reg.
(c), Example
, for more information. IRC
(c) provides two additional exceptions to the general rule that community income is taxed one-half to each spouse. Unlike IRC
, IRC
(c) provides relief for items of income only, as deﬁned in IRM
, Income Reporting Considerations of Community Property, not relief from lowed deductions as deﬁned in IRM
, Claiming of Deductions. The ﬁrst part of IRC

(c), known as traditional relief, applies only to cases. In cases where relief is granted, the NRS will be solely liable for the liability attributable to the item of community property income. See Treas.
Traditional relief under IRC
(c) has the following requirements: a. A joint return was not ﬁled for the taxable year for which the RS seeks relief; Note: If a joint return is ﬁled, IRC
(c) does not apply. Relief on a ﬁled return may be available under IRC
b. The RS does not include in gross income for such taxable year an of community income which would be attributable to NRS under IRC

(a) (For example, if the spouses were not subject to community property laws the item would be reportable by the NRS); c. The RS establishes he/she did not know and had no reason to know of such item of community income; and d. Considering all the facts and circumstances, it is inequitable to include such community item in the RS’s gross income. If all of the requirements are met, then the unreported item of income will be taxed wholly to the NRS, and not split. Knowledge or Reason to Know: For purposes of the knowledge requirement IRC

(c), a RS has knowledge or reason to know if he or she actually of the item of community income or a reasonable person in similar circum- stances would have known of the item of community income. All the facts circumstances are considered. Relevant factors include, but are not limited the nature of the item of community income, the amount of the item relative other income items, the couple’s ﬁnancial situation, the RS’s educational ground and business experience, and whether the item of community was reﬂected on prior years’ returns (e.g., investment income omitted that regularly reported on prior years’ returns). See Treas. Reg.

) for more information. The knowledge requirement is interpreted strictly. If a spouse is aware of the source of community income or an income producing activity, the RS is ered to have knowledge or reason to know of the item of community income even if the spouse does not know the speciﬁc amount received. IRC 66(c), a RS has knowledge or reason to know if he or she actually knew of the item of community income or a reasonable person in similar circum- stances would have known of the item of community income. Relevant factors include, but are not limited to, the nature of the item of community income, the amount of the item relative to other income items, the couple’s ﬁnancial situation, the RS’s educational back- ground and business experience, and whether the item of community income was reﬂected on prior years’ returns (e.g., investment income omitted that was regularly reported on prior years’ returns). The knowledge requirement is interpreted strictly. If a spouse is aware of the source of community income or an income producing activity, the RS is ered to have knowledge or reason to know of the item of community income even if the spouse does not know the speciﬁc amount received. See McGee Commissioner 979 F.2d 66 (5th Cir. 1992); Beck v. Commissioner, T.C. Memo, 2001-198; and Treas. Reg. 1.66-4(a)(2)(ii) for more information. ) A RS seeking relief from the operation of community property law under
(c) must request such relief on a Form

, Request for Innocent under Relief, or other written request, signed under penalties of perjury, stating relief is appropriate. The RS must also comply with the Service’s requests for information that will assist in identifying and locating the NRS. Treas. Reg.
(j) for more information. (
) To request relief from the federal income tax liability resulting from the operation of community property law under IRC
(c), a RS must ﬁle within for Filing a time period prescribed in the following subsections. (

) The earliest time for submitting a request for an amount omitted from the separate return, is the date the RS receives notiﬁcation of an audit or a or notice from the IRS stating there may be an outstanding liability with to that year. See Treas. Reg.
(j) for more information. (
) The latest time for requesting relief, except for requests for equitable relief, no later than

months before the expiration of the period of limitations on sessment, including extensions, against the NRS for the taxable year that the subject of the request for relief, unless the examination of the RS’s commences during that
-month period. (
) If the examination of the RS’s return commences during that
-month the latest time for requesting relief is
days after the commencement of examination. (

) The earliest time for submitting a request for equitable relief relating to a ciency is the date the RS receives notiﬁcation of an audit or a letter or from the IRS stating there may be an outstanding liability with regard to year. (
) The earliest time for submitting a request for equitable relief relating to a liability properly reported but unpaid is upon the ﬁling of the individual income tax return. (
) The latest time for requesting equitable relief is within any time period that collection statute or refund statute remains open. (
) The Service will not consider a premature request for relief under IRC See Treas. Reg.
)(iii) for more information. (

) In the case of a claim for traditional relief, a premature claim is a claim relief ﬁled for a taxable year prior to a notiﬁcation of an audit or a letter or notice from the Service indicating there may be an outstanding liability with regard to that year. Such notices or letters do not include notices issued pursuant to IRC
relating to Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) partnership proceedings but do include notices of computational justment to the partner or partner’s spouse, Form
, Report of Income Examination Changes, which compute the partner’s or partner’s spouse’s share of the partnership liability.

A RS seeking relief from the operation of community property law under IRC 66(c) must request such relief on a Form 8857, Request for Innocent Spouse Relief, or other written request, signed under penalties of perjury, stating why relief is appropriate. The RS must also comply with the Service’s reasonable requests for information that will assist in identifying and locating the NRS. Treas. Reg. 1.66-4(j) for more information.
The latest time for requesting equitable relief is within any time period that the collection statute or refund statute remains open.
Relief from Joint and Several (

) In the case of a claim for equitable relief involving an underpayment, a premature claim is a claim for relief received prior to the date the RS ﬁles individual federal income tax return for the taxable year in question. (

) In the case of a claim for equitable relief involving a deﬁciency, a claim is a claim received prior to notiﬁcation of an audit or letter or notice the IRS stating there may be an outstanding liability for that year. (
) If a RS in a community property state ﬁles a claim for relief from liability IRC
but the joint return election was invalid, the examiner should Joint Return consider whether any of the provisions of IRC
apply. If the joint election determined to be invalid and IRC
does not apply, then the appropriate community property split should be completed for the RS and the returns should be adjusted and/or secured. (
) If it is determined IRC

(c) applies, the items of community income able to the NRS are included in the gross income of the NRS as long as Against statute of limitations on assessment is still open. Thus, it is important to Relief Granted the statute of limitations on assessment against the NRS when processing claim under IRC
) In many instances for non-ﬁlers, the Service has ﬁled substitute returns for taxpayer under IRC

(b). In community property states, where there for Return indications the taxpayer was married, the Service will ﬁle substitute returns both spouses using the married ﬁling separate rates. Relief under IRC may be available to a RS in this instance, as no joint return was ﬁled by taxpayers. (

) The Service must send a notice to the NRS to inform them the RS ﬁled a claim for relief and provide the NRS an opportunity to submit any Requirement that should be considered in determining whether the RS should be relief from the operation of community property law. (
) This notice will be sent to the NRS’s last known address. (

) The Service may share with both spouses the information submitted by the other spouse, unless the Service determines the sharing of such will impair tax administration. Caution: Do not disclose the other spouse’s new last name, location, number or any information about the other spouse’s employment, or assets. (
) Any spouse denied relief may ﬁle an appeal with the Appeals Division to ministratively review the determination made under IRC
